A monarch is the head of a monarchy, a form of government in which a state or
polity is ruled by an individual who normally rules for life or until
abdication, and typically inherits the throne by birth. {{Cite web
  | title = Monarch publisher = CollinsDictionary.com. Collins English
  | Dictionary - Complete & Unabridged 11th Edition. url =
  | http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/monarch accessdate = 22
  | September 2012}}
Monarchs may be autocrats (as in many absolute monarchies) {{Cite book
  | last = Herb first = Michael title = All in the family: absolutism,
  | revolution, and democracy in the Middle East publisher = SUNY Press year =
  | 1999 location = New York page = 235 url =
  | http://books.google.com/books?id=i6hd9w64lcgC isbn = 978-0-7914-4168-
  | 8}} or may be ceremonial figureheads who exercise only reserve power,
  | with actual authority vested in a parliament or other governing bodies (as
  | in many constitutional monarchies). {{Cite book last = Spellman first =
  | W. M. title = Monarchies 1000â2000 publisher = Reaktion Books year = 2001
  | location = London pages = 22â23 url =
  | http://books.google.com/books?id=MRbExiEuYPsC| isbn = 978-1-86189-087-
  | 0}} In many cases, a monarch will also be linked with a state
  | religion. {{Cite book last = Harris first = Nathanial title = Systems of
  | Government: Monarchy publisher = Evans Brothers year = 2009 location =
  | London page = 38 url = http://books.google.com.my/books?id=o5SKJanyblIC|
  | isbn = 978-0-237-53932-0}} Most states only have a single monarch at
  | any given time, although a regent may rule when the monarch is a minor, not
  | present, or otherwise incapable of ruling. {{cite web title = Regent
  | publisher = CollinsDictionary.com. Collins English Dictionary - Complete &
  | Unabridged 11th
Edition.
  | url = http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/Regent accessdate
  | = September 22, 2012}} Cases in which two monarchs rule simultaneously
  | over a single state, as is the current situation in Andorra, are known as
  | coregencies. {{Cite book last = Hindley first = Geoffrey
  | title = The Royal Families of Europe publisher = Constable & Robinson year =
  | 2000 location = London pages = 1â6 url = isbn = 978-0-7867-0828-4}}

Monarchs are distinguished by their titles and styles, which in most cases are
defined by tradition, and guaranteed under the state's constitution. A variety
of titles are applied in English; for example, "king" and "queen", "prince" and
"princess", "emperor" and "empress". Although they will be addressed differently
in their local languages, the names and titles in the list below have been
styled using the common English equivalent. Roman numerals, used to distinguish
related rulers with the same name, {{Cite book
  | title = Merriam-Webster's manual for writers and editors publisher = Merriam-
  | Webster, Inc year = 1998 location = Springfield, United States page = 94 url
  | = http://books.google.com/books?id=7C6V9zRxSPkC isbn = 978-0-87779-622-
  | 0}} have been applied where typical.

In political and sociocultural studies, monarchies are normally associated with
hereditary rule; most monarchs, in both historical and contemporary contexts,
have been born and raised within a royal family. {{Cite book
  | last = Forty first = Sandra coauthors = Millidge, Judith; Riley, Ed title =
  | World Royal Families publisher = Book Sales, Inc year = 2009 location =
  | United States page = 94 isbn = 978-0-7858-2530-2}} Succession has been
  | defined using a variety of distinct formulae, such as proximity of blood,
  | primogeniture, and agnatic seniority. Some monarchies, however, are not
  | hereditary, and the ruler is instead determined through an elective process;
  | a modern example is the throne of Malaysia. . These systems defy
  | the model concept of a monarchy, but are commonly considered as such because
  | they retain certain associative characteristics. {{Cite book last =
  | Bouvier first = John coauthors = Rawle, Francis title = Bouvier's Law
  | Dictionary and Concise Encyclopedia volume = 2 edition = 3rd publisher =
  | Vernon Law Book Company year = 1914 pages = 2237â2238}} Many systems
  | use a combination of hereditary and elective elements, where the election or
  | nomination of a successor is restricted to members of a royal
  | bloodline. {{Cite book last = Shawcross first = William title =
  | Cambodia's new deal: a report publisher = Carnegie Endowment for
  | International Peace year = 1994 page = 106 isbn = 978-0-87003-051-
  | 2}} {{Cite book last = Garner first = James Wilford title =
  | Introduction to Political Science: A Treatise on the Origin, Nature,
  | Functions, and Organization of the State publisher = American Book Company
  | year = 1910 pages = 169â178 isbn = 978-1-115-59599-5}}

Entries below are listed beside their respective dominions, which are organised
alphabetically. These monarchs reign as head of state in their respective
sovereign states. Monarchs reigning over a constituent division, cultural or
traditional polity are listed under constituent monarchs. For current claimants
to abolished thrones, see pretenders.
